presenter.name: Ichiro Yasuda, MD, PhD.

presenter.bio: EUS-guided CPN/CGN: Technique, efficacy and complications

slide.title: EUS-guided CPN/CGN: Technique, efficacy and complications
slide.titleNormalized: eus-guided cpn/cgn: technique, efficacy and complications
slide.text: EUS-guided CPN/CGN: Technique, efficacy and complications Ichiro Yasuda, MD, PhD. Department of Gastroenterology, Teikyo University Mizonokuchi Hospital, Kawasaki, Japan

slide.title: Basic Theory of Celiac Plexus Neurolysis
slide.titleNormalized: basic theory of celiac plexus neurolysis
slide.notes: The celiac plexus surrounds the celiac artery and the superior mesenteric artery, and it consists of several ganglia and connecting neural rami. It transmits pain sensations from the upper abdominal organs such as the pancreas, liver, gallbladder, stomach, and ascending colon. The celiac plexus neurolysis (CPN) is used to disrupt the transmission of such pain signals by injecting neurolytic agent into the celiac plexus.
slide.notesNormalized: the celiac plexus surrounds the celiac artery and the superior mesenteric artery, and it consists of several ganglia and connecting neural rami. it transmits pain sensations from the upper abdominal organs such as the pancreas, liver, gallbladder, stomach, and ascending colon. the celiac plexus neurolysis (cpn) is used to disrupt the transmission of such pain signals by injecting neurolytic agent into the celiac plexus.
slide.notesHtml:
The celiac plexus surrounds the celiac artery and the superior mesenteric artery, and it consists of several ganglia and connecting neural rami.

It transmits pain sensations from the upper abdominal organs such as the pancreas, liver, gallbladder, stomach, and ascending colon.

The celiac plexus neurolysis (CPN) is used to disrupt the transmission of such pain signals by injecting neurolytic agent into the celiac plexus.
slide.text: Celiac artery (CA) Ganglion Ganglion Ganglion Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) Rt.- greater splanchnic nerve Lt.- greater splanchnic nerve 2 The CPN is used to disrupt the transmission of pain signals from the afferent nerves to the spinal cord by injecting neurolytic agent into the celiac plexus. Basic Theory of Celiac Plexus Neurolysis

slide.title: Various approaches for CPN
slide.notes: The celiac plexus neurolysis was initially described as an intraoperative technique by Kappis in 1914. Since then, it has been performed under radiographic, fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasonographic guidance. In addition, EUS-guided technique was recently introduced by Wiersema.
slide.notesNormalized: the celiac plexus neurolysis was initially described as an intraoperative technique by kappis in 1914. since then, it has been performed under radiographic, fluoroscopic, ct, or ultrasonographic guidance. in addition, eus-guided technique was recently introduced by wiersema.
slide.notesHtml:
The celiac plexus neurolysis was initially described as an intraoperative technique by Kappis in 1914.

Since then, it has been performed under radiographic, fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasonographic guidance.

In addition, EUS-guided technique was recently introduced by Wiersema.
slide.text: Kappis M (1914): Intraoperative Radiographic Fluoroscopic CT-guided US-guided Wiersema MJ (1996): EUS-guided Various approaches for CPN 3

slide.title: Indications of CPN
slide.notes: The indications of CPN is pain originated from the upper abdominal organs. The most major indication of this procedure is pancreatic cancer pain, because pain is a common symptom reported by 90% of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer, and it represents a major issue in the management of the patients. Pain due to chronic pancreatitis is also indicated.
slide.notesNormalized: the indications of cpn is pain originated from the upper abdominal organs. the most major indication of this procedure is pancreatic cancer pain, because pain is a common symptom reported by 90% of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer, and it represents a major issue in the management of the patients. pain due to chronic pancreatitis is also indicated.
slide.notesHtml:
The indications of CPN is pain originated from the upper abdominal organs.

The most major indication of this procedure is pancreatic cancer pain, because pain is a common symptom reported by 90% of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer, and it represents a major issue in the management of the patients.

Pain due to chronic pancreatitis is also indicated.
slide.text: Indications of CPN 4 Upper abdominal cancer pain Pancreatic cancer, Biliary cancer, Gastric cancer, …. Chronic pancreatitis Pain is a common symptom reported by 90% of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer. (Caraceni A. Cancer 1996) Pain originated from the upper abdominal organs

slide.title: Techniques of EUS-CPN
slide.notes: Two techniques are used for EUS-CPN. One is the central technique. In this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected at the base of the celiac axis. Another technique is the bilateral technique. In this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected on both sides of the celiac axis.
slide.notesNormalized: two techniques are used for eus-cpn. one is the central technique. in this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected at the base of the celiac axis. another technique is the bilateral technique. in this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected on both sides of the celiac axis.
slide.notesHtml:
Two techniques are used for EUS-CPN.

One is the central technique.

In this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected at the base of the celiac axis.

Another technique is the bilateral technique. In this technique, a neurolytic agent is injected on both sides of the celiac axis.
slide.text: Techniques of EUS-CPN Central technique Bilateral technique 5 The neurolytic agent is injected at the base or on both sides of the celiac axis. CA Ao SMA needle (probable location of the celiac ganglia)

slide.title: EUS-CPN (Central technique)
slide.notes: First, I will show the video clip of the central technique. After the abdominal aorta is visualized in the longitudinal plane on the EUS image, the aorta is traced to identify the CA. Subsequently, a needle is advanced to a point just above the point where the CA originates from the aorta. Absolute ethanol is injected into the region until the echogenic cloud widespread sufficiently.
slide.notesNormalized: first, i will show the video clip of the central technique. after the abdominal aorta is visualized in the longitudinal plane on the eus image, the aorta is traced to identify the ca. subsequently, a needle is advanced to a point just above the point where the ca originates from the aorta. absolute ethanol is injected into the region until the echogenic cloud widespread sufficiently.
slide.notesHtml:
First, I will show the video clip of the central technique.

After the abdominal aorta is visualized in the longitudinal plane on the EUS image, the aorta is traced to identify the CA. Subsequently, a needle is advanced to a point just above the point where the CA originates from the aorta.

Absolute ethanol is injected into the region until the echogenic cloud widespread sufficiently.

slide.title: EUS-CPN (Bilateral technique)
slide.notes: I will also show the bilateral technique. After the origin of the CA is identified, the echoendoscope is rotated clockwise until the CA and SMA are no longer visible. The needle is then advanced toward the left, alongside the CA and SMA, up to a position lateral to the point where the SMA originates from the aorta. Absolute ethanol is injected into this region. Next, the echoendoscope is rotated counterclockwise until the CA and SMA are no longer visible. The needle is advanced to the right lateral base of the SMA, and absolute ethanol is injected once again.
slide.notesNormalized: i will also show the bilateral technique. after the origin of the ca is identified, the echoendoscope is rotated clockwise until the ca and sma are no longer visible. the needle is then advanced toward the left, alongside the ca and sma, up to a position lateral to the point where the sma originates from the aorta. absolute ethanol is injected into this region. next, the echoendoscope is rotated counterclockwise until the ca and sma are no longer visible. the needle is advanced to the right lateral base of the sma, and absolute ethanol is injected once again.
slide.notesHtml:
I will also show the bilateral technique.

After the origin of the CA is identified, the echoendoscope is rotated clockwise until the CA and SMA are no longer visible.

The needle is then advanced toward the left, alongside the CA and SMA, up to a position lateral to the point where the SMA originates from the aorta.

Absolute ethanol is injected into this region.

Next, the echoendoscope is rotated counterclockwise until the CA and SMA are no longer visible.

The needle is advanced to the right lateral base of the SMA, and absolute ethanol is injected once again.

slide.title: EUS-guided direct celiac ganglia neurolysis (EUS-CGN)
slide.notes: In addition, another new technique has recently been introduced. In this technique, the celiac ganglia is punctured and neurolytic agent is directly injected in it.
slide.notesNormalized: in addition, another new technique has recently been introduced. in this technique, the celiac ganglia is punctured and neurolytic agent is directly injected in it.
slide.notesHtml:
In addition, another new technique has recently been introduced.

In this technique, the celiac ganglia is punctured and neurolytic agent is directly injected in it.
slide.text: 8 EUS-guided direct celiac ganglia neurolysis (EUS-CGN) Levy MJ. Am J Gastroenterol 2008, Ascunce G. Gastrointest Endosc 2011, LeBlanc JK, Diagn Ther Endosc 2013, Doi S. Endoscopy 2013, Ishiwatari H. World J Gastroenterol 2014.

slide.notes: In this case, two celiac ganglia are identified at a site just medial to the left adrenal gland. A needle puncture was made, and the needle was advanced to the distal end of the lower ganglion. Thereafter, absolute ethanol was injected. After the injection, the ganglion became hyperechoic. As the needle was withdrawn, ethanol was injected into the ganglion until identification of the ganglion became difficult. Next, the upper ganglion is punctured, and ethanol is injected. This procedure was repeated until identification of all ganglia became difficult.
slide.notesNormalized: in this case, two celiac ganglia are identified at a site just medial to the left adrenal gland. a needle puncture was made, and the needle was advanced to the distal end of the lower ganglion. thereafter, absolute ethanol was injected. after the injection, the ganglion became hyperechoic. as the needle was withdrawn, ethanol was injected into the ganglion until identification of the ganglion became difficult. next, the upper ganglion is punctured, and ethanol is injected. this procedure was repeated until identification of all ganglia became difficult.
slide.notesHtml:
In this case, two celiac ganglia are identified at a site just medial to the left adrenal gland.

A needle puncture was made, and the needle was advanced to the distal end of the lower ganglion.

Thereafter, absolute ethanol was injected.

After the injection, the ganglion became hyperechoic.

As the needle was withdrawn, ethanol was injected into the ganglion until identification of the ganglion became difficult.

Next, the upper ganglion is punctured, and ethanol is injected.

This procedure was repeated until identification of all ganglia became difficult.

slide.title: Pain relief by EUS-CPN
slide.notes: Two meta-analysis have previously been published. They showed that pain relief was achieved in around 73 to 80% of patients with pancreatic cancer pain and in 50-60% of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.notesNormalized: two meta-analysis have previously been published. they showed that pain relief was achieved in around 73 to 80% of patients with pancreatic cancer pain and in 50-60% of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.notesHtml:
Two meta-analysis have previously been published.

They showed that pain relief was achieved in around 73 to 80% of patients with pancreatic cancer pain and in 50-60% of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.text: Pain relief by EUS-CPN 10 The pooled proportion of patients with pancreatic cancer that showed pain relief was 80.12% (95% CI = 74.47–85.22). In patients with pain due to chronic pancreatitis, EUS-guided CPN provided pain relief in 59.45% (95% CI = 54.51–64.30). 2 meta-analysis Puli SR. Dig Dis Sci 2009 Efficacy of endoscopic ultrasound-guided celiac plexus block and celiac plexus neurolysis for managing abdominal pain associated with chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer. Kaufman M, Singh G, Das S, Concha-Parra R, Erber J, Micames C, Gress F. Kaufman M. J Clin Gastroenterol 2010 EUS-guided CPN was 72.54% effective in managing pain due to pancreatic cancer and is a reasonable option for patients with tolerance to narcotic analgesics. EUS-guided CPB was 51.46% effective in managing chronic abdominal pain in patients with chronic pancreatitis.

slide.title: Central vs. Bilateral technique
slide.notes: Some studies have suggested that the bilateral technique was more effective than the central technique. But it is also true that the central technique is easier and possibly safer than the bilateral technique.
slide.notesNormalized: some studies have suggested that the bilateral technique was more effective than the central technique. but it is also true that the central technique is easier and possibly safer than the bilateral technique.
slide.notesHtml:
Some studies have suggested that the bilateral technique was more effective than the central technique.

But it is also true that the central technique is easier and possibly safer than the bilateral technique.
slide.text: Central vs. Bilateral technique Study design Central Bilateral P Sahai AV (Am J Gastroenterol 2009) Retrospective 45.9%a 70.4%a 0.0016 Puli SR (Dig Dis Sci 2009) Meta-analysis 46.0%b 84.5%b - LeBlanc JK (Gastrointest Endosc 2011) Prospective 69%b 81%b 0.340 a mean% of pain reduction, b % of patients with pain relief 11 Bilateral technique: more effective Central technique: easier and possibly safer

slide.title: EUS-CPN vs. EUS-CGN
slide.notes: Our multicenter RCT showed that EUS–CGN was significantly superior to conventional EUS–CPN (central technique) in cancer pain relief.
slide.notesNormalized: our multicenter rct showed that eus–cgn was significantly superior to conventional eus–cpn (central technique) in cancer pain relief.
slide.notesHtml: Our multicenter RCT showed that EUS–CGN was significantly superior to conventional EUS–CPN (central technique) in cancer pain relief.
slide.text: EUS-CPN vs. EUS-CGN 12 EUS–CGN was significantly superior to conventional EUS–CPN (central technique) in cancer pain relief. Doi S, Yasuda I, et al. Endoscopy 2013

slide.title: Complications of EUS-CPN
slide.notes: Complications of EUS-CPN included transient pain exacerbation, hypotension, diarrhea, and inebriation sometimes occurs. However, most of such complications are not serious.
slide.notesNormalized: complications of eus-cpn included transient pain exacerbation, hypotension, diarrhea, and inebriation sometimes occurs. however, most of such complications are not serious.
slide.notesHtml:
Complications of EUS-CPN included transient pain exacerbation, hypotension, diarrhea, and inebriation sometimes occurs.

However, most of such complications are not serious.
slide.text: Transient pain exacerbation (0-36.0%) Transient hypotension (0-33.0%) Transient diarrhea (0-23.4%) Inebriation (0-12.5%) Retroperitoneal hemorrhage (0-1.0%) Infectious complications (0-1.0%) GI bleeding (0-2.9%) Complications of EUS-CPN 13 Wiersema MJ. Gastrointest Endosc 1996, Harada N. Gastrointest Endosc Clin N Am 1997, Gress F. Am J Gastroenterol 1999, Gress F. Am J Gastroenterol 2001, Gunaratnam NT. Gastrointest Endosc 2001, Sakamoto H. Dig Endosc 2006, Levy MJ. Am J Gastroenterol 2008, Sahai AV. Am J Gastroenterol 2009, O’Toole TM. Endoscopy 2009, Sakamoto H. Am J Gastroenterol 2010, Iwata K. Dig Endosc 2011, LeBlanc JK. Gastrointest Endosc 2011, Ascunce G. Gastrointest Endosc 2011, Wiechowska-Kozlowska A. Gastroenterol Res Pract 2012, Seicean A. J Gastrointest Liver Dis 2013, LeBlanc JK, Diagn Ther Endosc 2013, Doi S. Endoscopy 2013, Tellez-Avila FI. Endosc Ultrasound 2013, Ishiwatari H. World J Gastroenterol 2014.

slide.title: Major complications of EUS-CPN
slide.notes: However, major complications have rarely been reported using EUS-CPN. Most of them were reported in the setting of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.notesNormalized: however, major complications have rarely been reported using eus-cpn. most of them were reported in the setting of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.notesHtml:
However, major complications have rarely been reported using EUS-CPN.

Most of them were reported in the setting of chronic pancreatitis.
slide.text: Major complications of EUS-CPN 14 Author Complication Indication Technique Substance Fujii L (Endoscopy 2012) Paraplegia PC CGN+CPN Bupivacaine+Alcohol 1mL(CGN)+23mL(CPN) Loeve US (GIE 2013) Necrosis & perforation of stomach & aorta/ dead CP Multiple CPN (13 sessions for 4 years) Bupivacaine 6-10mL + Alcohol 8-20mL Jang HY (Clin Endosc 2013) Liver & spleen infarction Stomach & small intestine ischemia/ dead Lung ca. Panc. meta CPN(central) Bupivacaine 5mL + Alcohol 10mL + Triamcinolone 1mL + Saline 3mL * * CA thrombosis + liver, lt-kidney, spleen, stomach, small intestine, and ascending colon infarction (20mL) (10mL) Gimeno-Garcia AZ. Endoscopy 2012 Major complications have rarely been reported using EUS-CPN. Most of bleeding complications occurred in the bilateral technique. Most of infectious complications were reported in the setting of chronic pancreatitis.

slide.title: Conclusions
slide.text: Conclusions EUS-CGN is significantly superior to EUS-CPN in providing cancer pain relief. 16 EUS-CPN is a relatively safe and effective method to reduce upper abdominal cancer pain. The actual techniques of EUS-CPN and EUS-CGN were shown.
